question: If $\mathbf{A}^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 \\ -2 & 10 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{B} = \frac{1}{2} \mathbf{A},$ then find $\mathbf{B}^{-1}.$
agents_response:
Since $\mathbf{B} = \frac{1}{2} \mathbf{A},$ we have $\mathbf{B}^{-1} = 2 \mathbf{A}^{-1},$ given that the inverse of scalar multiplication on a matrix is just the multiplication of the inverse of the scalar with the matrix. Therefore, $\mathbf{B}^{-1} = 2 \times \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 \\ -2 & 10 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 8 & 12 \\ -4 & 20 \end{pmatrix}.$ 
So, $\boxed{\mathbf{B}^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 8 & 12 \\ -4 & 20 \end{pmatrix}}.$
